Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the investigational drug, LY3009120, in patients with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of LY3009120 in patients with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis. The study will consist of a screening period of up to 28 days, a 12-week treatment period, and a 4-week follow-up period. Patients will be randomized to receive either LY3009120 or placebo. The primary endpoint is the proportion of patients achieving an Investigator's Global Assessment (IGA) score of 0 or 1 at Week 12.

A Phase 2, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Parallel-group, Multicenter Study to Evaluate the Efficacy, Safety, and Tolerability of LY3009120 in Patients With Moderate to Severe Atopic Dermatitis

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic heart failure (CHF). Methods: A total of 100 patients with CHF were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, which included aerobic and resistance training. The control group did not receive any exercise intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire (MLHFQ) at baseline and after 12 weeks. Results: The mean age of the participants was 62.1 ± 10.1 years, and 60% were male. The mean MLHFQ score was 20.1 ± 10.1 at baseline and 16.1 ± 10.1 after 12 weeks in the exercise group, and 20.1 ± 10.1 at baseline and 19.1 ± 10.1 after 12 weeks in the control group. The mean difference in the MLHFQ score between the exercise and control groups was ‐4.0 (95% confidence interval [CI], ‐6.0 to ‐2.0; P < 0.001). The mean difference in the MLHFQ score between the exercise and control groups was ‐4.0 (95% CI, ‐6.0 to ‐2.0; P < 0.001). Conclusion: A 12‐week exercise program improved the quality of life of patients with CHF.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the feasibility of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a behavioral intervention called Virtual Tai Chi Easy (VTCE) for opioid use disorder (OUD), anxiety, and chronic pain. The study will also examine the acceptability of the intervention and the feasibility of conducting a larger RCT.

Detailed Description
-----------------

The study will be conducted at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) and the VA San Diego Healthcare System (VASDHS). The study will enroll 30 participants with OUD, anxiety, and chronic pain. Participants will be randomized to either the intervention or a waitlist control group. The intervention group will receive the VTCE intervention for 12 weeks. The control group will receive the intervention after the 12-week study period. The study will assess the feasibility of conducting a larger RCT of VTCE for OUD, anxiety, and chronic pain. The study will also assess the acceptability of the intervention and the feasibility of conducting a larger RCT.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine whether a behavioral educational video can increase the rate of genetic testing in black men with prostate cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men and the second leading cause of cancer death in men in the United States. Black men are disproportionately affected by prostate cancer, with a 1.6-fold higher incidence and a 2.3-fold higher mortality rate compared to white men. The disparity in prostate cancer outcomes between black and white men is largely due to differences in access to care and treatment. Genetic testing is an important tool for identifying patients who may benefit from targeted therapies and for identifying patients who may be at increased risk for developing other cancers. However, genetic testing is underutilized in the black population, with only 10-15% of eligible patients undergoing testing. One potential reason for this disparity is a lack of knowledge about the benefits of genetic testing. The investigators hypothesize that a behavioral educational video can increase the rate of genetic testing in black men with prostate cancer. The investigators will conduct a randomized controlled trial to test this hypothesis. The investigators will enroll 100 black men with prostate cancer who are eligible for genetic testing. The participants will be randomized to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive a behavioral educational video about the benefits of genetic testing. The control group will receive standard of care education about genetic testing. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of genetic testing in the two groups. The investigators will also assess the impact of the intervention on knowledge about genetic testing and attitudes towards genetic testing.

Utilization of Educational Interventions in Completion of Genetic Testing in Black Patients With High-Risk Prostate Cancer

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a behavioral educational video in increasing the rates of germline genetic testing completion in patients with prostate cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men in the United States, with an estimated 268,490 new cases and 34,50 deaths in 2022. Germline genetic testing is recommended for patients with prostate cancer who meet certain criteria, including those with a family history of prostate cancer or other hereditary cancer syndromes. However, uptake of germline genetic testing in prostate cancer is low, with rates ranging from 10-20%. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a behavioral educational video in increasing the rates of germline genetic testing completion in patients with prostate cancer. The study will be conducted in a single-center, randomized controlled trial. Patients with prostate cancer who meet the inclusion criteria will be randomized to either the intervention or control group. The intervention group will receive a behavioral educational video on germline genetic testing in prostate cancer, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of germline genetic testing completion within 6 months of enrollment. Secondary outcome measures will include patient knowledge and attitudes towards germline genetic testing, as well as patient satisfaction with the educational video. The study will also evaluate the feasibility of implementing the educational video in a clinical setting. The study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of a behavioral educational video in increasing the rates of germline genetic testing completion in patients with prostate cancer.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a new treatment for patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps (CRSwNP). The study will compare the efficacy of a new treatment with a standard treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps (CRSwNP) is a common condition that affects millions of people worldwide. It is characterized by inflammation of the nasal passages and the production of nasal polyps, which are small, non-cancerous growths that can cause breathing difficulties and other symptoms. Current treatments for CRSwNP include medications and surgery, but these treatments are often ineffective or have significant side effects. The investigators are conducting a clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy of a new treatment for CRSwNP. The new treatment is a combination of two medications that are currently used to treat other conditions. The study will compare the efficacy of the new treatment with a standard treatment for CRSwNP. The study will enroll 100 patients with CRSwNP who will be randomly assigned to receive either the new treatment or the standard treatment. The study will last for 12 weeks, and participants will be evaluated at the beginning of the study and at the end of the study. The primary outcome measure will be the change in the severity of nasal symptoms. Secondary outcome measures will include the change in the size of the nasal polyps and the change in the quality of life.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Parallel-Group Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of a New Treatment for Chronic Rhinosinusitis With Nasal Polyps

Chronic Rhinosinusitis With Nasal Polyps

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the use of the CytoSorb® device in patients with acute on chronic liver failure (ACLF).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be conducted in two parts: a prospective, single-arm, open-label, single-center, pilot study and a prospective, randomized, controlled, multi-center, open-label, phase II study. The pilot study will be conducted at a single center in Belgium and will enroll up to 10 patients with ACLF. The phase II study will be conducted at up to 10 centers in Europe and will enroll up to 100 patients with ACLF. The primary objective of the pilot study is to evaluate the safety and feasibility of the CytoSorb® device in patients with ACLF. The primary objective of the phase II study is to evaluate the efficacy of the CytoSorb® device in patients with ACLF. The secondary objectives of both studies are to evaluate the safety and feasibility of the CytoSorb® device in patients with ACLF.

Official Title
-----------------
A Prospective, Single-arm, Open-label, Single-center, Pilot Study and a Prospective, Randomized, Controlled, Multi-center, Open-label, Phase II Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of the CytoSorb® Device in Patients With Acute on Chronic Liver Failure

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the exercise group (n = 30) and the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not. The quality of life of the patients was evaluated using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) before and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 64.2 ± 7.1 years, and 53.3% were male. The mean SGRQ score of the patients in the exercise group decreased from 48.3 ± 10.1 to 38.1 ± 10.1 (p < 0.001), while the mean SGRQ score of the patients in the control group increased from 47.8 ± 10.1 to 49.1 ± 10.1 (p = 0.001). The mean SGRQ score of the patients in the exercise group was significantly lower than that of the patients in the control group after the intervention (p < 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Okay, based on the information you've provided, I have some suggestions for the design of your study arms. For the active comparator arm, I recommend using the Hot EMR technique. This involves an initial submucosal injection of physiological solution and methylene blue, followed by 'piece-meal' resection using a 10 or 15 millimeter diathermic snare and ablation of the margins with the snare tip. This arm will serve as a comparison to evaluate the conventional hot EMR technique.

For the experimental arm, I suggest using the Cold EMR technique. This involves an initial submucosal injection of physiological solution and methylene blue, followed by 'piece-meal' resection using a dedicated cold snare. This technique is hypothesized to have advantages such as reduced thermal injury and potentially lower recurrence rates. By comparing this arm to the hot EMR arm, you can determine if the cold EMR technique is a feasible alternative for large colonic adenomas.

Exactly! And for the experimental arm, the participant group/arm will be patients undergoing mucosectomy using a cold snare technique, and the intervention/treatment will involve the use of a dedicated cold snare for resection, along with the initial submucosal injection and 'piece-meal' resection.

Brief summary
=================
This is a phase 2 study of genetically risk-stratified combination of venetoclax, ibrutinib, and rituximab (with and without navitoclax) in patients with relapsed and refractory mantle cell lymphoma (MCL). The study will enroll patients with MCL who have received at least one prior line of systemic therapy and require treatment according to the investigator’s opinion. Patients will be stratified into three groups based on their genetic risk profile: low, intermediate, and high. Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of the combination of the investigational drug, AZD1775, and the standard of care chemotherapy, bendamustine, in patients with relapsed or refractory diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 1b, open-label, multicenter, dose-escalation study of AZD1775 in combination with bendamustine in patients with relapsed or refractory DLBCL. The study will be conducted in two parts. Part 1 will be a dose-escalation study to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of AZD1775 in combination with bendamustine. Part 2 will be a dose-expansion study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the MTD determined in Part 1.

A Phase 1b, Open-Label, Multicenter, Dose-Escalation Study of AZD1775 in Combination With Bendamustine in Patients With Relapsed or Refractory Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma

The first arm, called the "Facilitated Group ACP Session," will involve participants attending a one-time 90-minute facilitated group ACP session. During this session, they will review the movie version of the PREPARE program, including a new PSH-specific video and PREPARE easy-to-read advance directives with the new PSH-specific content and cover letters. The group facilitators will adhere to standardized scripts and protocols to engage participants in ACP through group sessions.

The second study arm is called "Facilitated one-on-one ACP visits." Participants in this arm will also attend a one-time 90-minute ACP session, but in a one-on-one setting with a facilitator. They will review the movie version of the PREPARE program, along with the new PSH-specific video and PREPARE easy-to-read advance directives. The facilitator will adhere to scripts and protocols to engage participants in advance care planning, tailoring the session to their unique circumstances.

Abstract:
Background: The COVID‐19 pandemic has led to an increase in the number of patients requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. Tracheal stenosis is a known complication of intubation and mechanical ventilation, and it is expected that the number of cases will increase due to the COVID‐19 pandemic. However, there is limited data on the incidence and risk factors of tracheal stenosis in COVID‐19 patients. Objective: To determine the incidence of tracheal stenosis in COVID‐19 patients and identify risk factors associated with its development. Methods: This is a retrospective cohort study of COVID‐19 patients who were intubated and mechanically ventilated at a tertiary care hospital in New York City. Patient demographics, clinical characteristics, and outcomes were collected from the electronic medical record. The primary outcome was the development of tracheal stenosis within 6 months of intubation. Results: A total of 100 COVID‐19 patients were included in the study. The median age was 62 years (IQR 52‐71), and 58% were male. The median duration of mechanical ventilation was 10 days (IQR 7‐14), and the median length of hospital stay was 14 days (IQR 10‐20). The incidence of tracheal stenosis was 10%, with a median time to diagnosis of 3 months (IQR 2‐4). Risk factors for tracheal stenosis included male sex (OR 3.0, 95% CI 1.0‐8.9, p=0.04), intubation duration >10 days (OR 3.0, 95% CI 1.0‐8.9, p=0.04), and length of hospital stay >14 days (OR 3.0, 95% CI 1.0‐8.9, p=0.04).

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life (QoL) of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This randomized controlled trial was conducted on 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the intervention and control groups. The intervention group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group received routine care. The QoL of the patients was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) before and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 63.33 ± 7.18 years, and the mean duration of COPD was 5.17 ± 3.18 years. The mean SGRQ score in the intervention group decreased from 48.33 ± 10.01 to 35.33 ± 10.01 (P < 0.001), while in the control group, it increased from 48.33 ± 10.01 to 50.33 ± 10.01 (P < 0.001). The mean difference in the SGRQ score between the two groups was ‐13.00 ± 10.01 (P < 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the QoL of patients with COPD.

The study will last for up to 2 years.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, open-label, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of REGN2810 (cemiplimab) in combination with platinum-doublet chemotherapy in adult patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) in the United States (US).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, open-label, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of REGN2810 (cemiplimab) in combination with platinum-doublet chemotherapy in adult patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) in the United States (US). The study will consist of a screening period, a treatment period, and a follow-up period. The treatment period will consist of a 21-day cycle. Patients will receive REGN2810 (cemiplimab) 350 mg intravenously (IV) on Day 1 of each cycle and platinum-doublet chemotherapy on Day 1 of each cycle. Patients will continue treatment until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, withdrawal of consent, or death. Patients who discontinue treatment will be followed for survival.

Official Title

A Phase 2, Open-Label, Multicenter Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of REGN2810 (Cemiplimab) in Combination With Platinum-Doublet Chemotherapy in Adult Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) in the United States (US)

Abstract:
The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life (QoL) of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). A total of 40 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 20) or a control group (n = 20). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, which included aerobic and resistance training. The control group did not receive any intervention. The QoL of the patients was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. The exercise group showed a significant improvement in the total SGRQ score (p < 0.001), as well as in the symptoms, activity, and impact domains (p < 0.001 for all). The control group showed no significant changes in the SGRQ scores. The exercise group also showed a significant improvement in the 6‐minute walk test (6MWT) distance (p < 0.001) and the peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak) (p < 0.001) compared to the control group. In conclusion, a 12‐week exercise program can improve the QoL of patients with COPD, as measured by the SGRQ. The exercise program also improved the physical fitness of the patients, as measured by the 6MWT distance and the VO2peak.

Despite advances in medical therapy, the mortality rate has not improved significantly in the past decade. One of the main challenges in the management of heart failure is the development of resistance to medical therapy. This is often due to the development of compensatory mechanisms that lead to a progressive decline in cardiac function. One of the most important compensatory mechanisms is the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). The RAAS is a hormonal system that regulates blood pressure and fluid balance. In heart failure, the RAAS is activated in response to decreased cardiac output, leading to increased blood pressure and fluid retention. This can further worsen heart failure symptoms and lead to a vicious cycle of worsening heart failure and increased mortality. Another important compensatory mechanism is the activation of the sympathetic nervous system. The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for the fight-or-flight response, and it is activated in response to decreased cardiac output. In heart failure, the sympathetic nervous system is activated in an attempt to increase cardiac output and maintain blood pressure. However, this can lead to further worsening of heart failure symptoms and increased mortality. The activation of the RAAS and sympathetic nervous system can also lead to the development of metabolic dysfunction. HF is a leading cause of hospitalization and mortality, and its prevalence is expected to increase in the coming years due to the aging population and the increasing prevalence of risk factors such as diabetes, obesity, and hypertension. Despite advances in medical therapy, HF remains a significant public health problem. The current standard of care for HF includes diuretics, beta-blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs). However, these therapies have limitations, and there is a need for new and more effective treatments. In recent years, several new classes of drugs have been developed for the treatment of HF, including SGLT2 inhibitors, sGC stimulators, and ARNI. These drugs have shown promising results in clinical trials, and their mechanism of action is thought to be related to their effects on the metabolism of the heart and other organs. However, the metabolic response to these therapies is not well understood. The purpose of this study is to investigate the metabolic response to the initiation of SGLT2 inhibitors, sGC stimulators, and ARNI in heart failure patients. =================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, open-label, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pembrolizumab in patients with unresectable locally advanced or metastatic transitional cell carcinoma of the urothelium.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, open-label, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pembrolizumab in patients with unresectable locally advanced or metastatic transitional cell carcinoma of the urothelium. Patients will receive pembrolizumab 200 mg or 400 mg intravenously every 3 weeks for up to 35 cycles. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the efficacy of pembrolizumab in patients with unresectable locally advanced or metastatic transitional cell carcinoma of the urothelium. For the extracorporeal shock wave group, we can assign patients with lateral epicondylitis to this arm. The intervention would be a physiotherapy program consisting of hot packs, TENS, stretching, and eccentric strengthening exercises. Additionally, they would receive 3 sessions of ESWT at 1.8 bar, 10.0 Hz, 2000 beats once a week for 3 weeks. This would be in addition to the ten-day physiotherapy program. What do you think?

For the ultrasound group, we can also assign patients with lateral epicondylitis. The intervention would be the same physiotherapy program as the extracorporeal shock wave group. Additionally, they would receive ultrasound therapy at 1.5 watt/cm2 in continuous mode to the painful area for 5 minutes, 5 days a week for two weeks. This would be in addition to the ten-day physiotherapy program. How does that sound?

For the dexamethasone iontophoresis group, we can assign patients with lateral epicondylitis. The intervention would be the same physiotherapy program as the other groups. Additionally, they would receive dexamethasone iontophoresis therapy for 10 days. In each session, 0.1% dexamethasone ophthalmic pomade would be applied to the anodal electrode and placed on the lateral epicondyle. Galvanic current would be applied at 0.1-0.2 milliampere/cm2. This would also be in addition to the ten-day physiotherapy program. What do you think?

Great! Now, let me summarize the full study arms:

Study Arms:
1. Extracorporeal shock wave group:
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients with lateral epicondylitis who will receive extracorporeal shock wave therapy.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Patients in this group will undergo a physiotherapy program consisting of hot packs, TENS, stretching, and eccentric strengthening exercises. Additionally, they will receive 3 sessions of ESWT at 1.8 bar, 10.0 Hz, 2000 beats once a week for 3 weeks.

2. Ultrasound group:
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients with lateral epicondylitis who will receive ultrasound therapy.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Patients in this group will undergo the same physiotherapy program as the ESWT group. Additionally, they will receive ultrasound therapy at 1.5 watt/cm2 in continuous mode to the painful area for 5 minutes, 5 days a week for two weeks.

3. Dexamethasone iontophoresis group:
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients with lateral epicondylitis who will receive dexamethasone iontophoresis therapy.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Patients in this group will undergo the same physiotherapy program as the other groups. Additionally, they will receive dexamethasone iontophoresis therapy for 10 days, with 0.1% dexamethasone ophthalmic pomade applied to the anodal electrode and placed on the lateral epicondyle. Galvanic current will be applied at 0.1-0.2 milliampere/cm2 in each session.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new formulation of 0.1% timolol maleate (TM) in the treatment of glaucoma or ocular hypertension. Methods: This was a multicenter, randomized, double‐masked, parallel‐group, vehicle‐controlled, phase 3 study. Patients with primary open‐angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension were randomized to receive either 0.1% TM or vehicle twice daily for 12 weeks. The primary efficacy endpoint was the change in intraocular pressure (IOP) from baseline to week 12. Secondary efficacy endpoints included the proportion of patients achieving a ≥20% reduction in IOP from baseline to week 12, the proportion of patients achieving a ≥30% reduction in IOP from baseline to week 12, and the proportion of patients achieving a ≥20% reduction in IOP from baseline to week 12 in patients with baseline IOP ≥25 mmHg. Safety was assessed by monitoring adverse events. Results: A total of 1,000 patients were randomized to receive 0.1% TM (n = 500) or vehicle (n = 500). The mean change in IOP from baseline to week 12 was ‐5.1 mmHg in the 0.1% TM group and ‐2.9 mmHg in the vehicle group (P < 0.001). The proportion of patients achieving a ≥20% reduction in IOP from baseline to week 12 was 80.0% in the 0.1% TM group and 44.0% in the vehicle group (P < 0.001). The proportion of patients achieving a ≥30% reduction in IOP from baseline to week 12 was 58.0% in the 0.1% TM group and 24.0% in the vehicle group (P < 0.001). Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of using the GORE® SYNECOR Intraperitoneal (IP) Biomaterial in combination with laparoscopic closure of the hernia defect in patients undergoing incisional hernia repair. The study will compare the outcomes of this technique to the standard approach of using the GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial without defect closure. The study will enroll 100 patients who are undergoing incisional hernia repair and will be randomized to either study arm A or study arm B. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of postoperative complications within 30 days of surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include hernia recurrence, mesh bulging, and patient satisfaction.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Incisional hernia repair is a common surgical procedure that is performed to repair a hernia that has developed through a surgical incision. The GORE® SYNECOR Intraperitoneal (IP) Biomaterial is a hybrid mesh that is designed to provide strength and support to the repair site while also promoting tissue ingrowth and integration. In this study, the investigators will evaluate the effectiveness of using the GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial in combination with laparoscopic closure of the hernia defect in patients undergoing incisional hernia repair. The study will compare the outcomes of this technique to the standard approach of using the GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial without defect closure. The study will enroll 100 patients who are undergoing incisional hernia repair and will be randomized to either study arm A or study arm B. Study arm A will receive the GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial in combination with laparoscopic closure of the hernia defect, while study arm B will receive the GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial without defect closure. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of postoperative complications within 30 days of surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include hernia recurrence, mesh bulging, and patient satisfaction.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial in the treatment of incisional hernia.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Incisional hernia is a common complication of abdominal surgery, with an estimated incidence of 10-20%. The standard treatment for incisional hernia is surgical repair, which involves the placement of a mesh to reinforce the weakened abdominal wall. However, traditional meshes can cause complications such as infection, pain, and mesh shrinkage. The GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial is a new type of mesh that is designed to address these issues. It is a hybrid mesh that combines a synthetic mesh with a biologic component, which is derived from porcine small intestine submucosa. The biologic component is designed to promote tissue ingrowth and integration, while the synthetic mesh provides strength and support. The GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial has been shown to be safe and effective in the treatment of ventral hernia in a previous clinical study. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial in the treatment of incisional hernia. The study will enroll patients with incisional hernia who are scheduled for elective hernia repair. Patients will be randomized to receive either the GORE® SYNECOR IP Biomaterial or a standard mesh. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of hernia recurrence at 12 months post-surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include the incidence of complications, pain scores, and patient satisfaction.

Official Title
-----------------
Early Surgical Outcomes in the Use of Hybrid Mesh for Incisional Hernia Repair: Results From a Multicenter Italian Study

Incisional Hernia

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the feasibility of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the efficacy of a 12-week exercise intervention in combination with neoadjuvant chemotherapy in women with breast cancer. The study will also assess the feasibility of conducting a larger RCT to evaluate the efficacy of the intervention.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, with an estimated 281,550 new cases and 43,600 deaths in 2022 in the United States. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) is a standard treatment for breast cancer, which is given before surgery to shrink the tumor and improve surgical outcomes. However, NAC can have significant side effects, including fatigue, nausea, and muscle weakness, which can impact patients' quality of life and ability to participate in physical activity. Exercise has been shown to improve physical function, quality of life, and cancer-related fatigue in breast cancer patients. However, there is limited evidence on the efffficacy of exercise during NAC. The purpose of this study is to determine the feasibility of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the efficacy of a 12-week exercise intervention in combination with NAC in women with breast cancer. The study will also assess the feasibility of conducting a larger RCT to evaluate the efficacy of the intervention. The study will enroll 30 women with breast cancer who are scheduled to receive NAC. Participants will be randomized to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive a 12-week exercise intervention, which will include aerobic and resistance training. The control group will receive standard care. Both groups will receive NAC as per standard of care. The primary outcome measure will be the feasibility of conducting a larger RCT, which will be assessed by the number of participants who complete the study, the number of participants who drop out, and the number of participants who complete the intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in physical function, quality of life, and cancer-related fatigue.

Brief summary
=================
Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and neoadjuvant chemotherapy is the standard of care for many patients. However, the response to chemotherapy can be variable, and some patients may not achieve a pathologic complete response (pCR). Physical exercise has been shown to have beneficial effects on cancer outcomes, but its role in improving the response to chemotherapy is not well understood. This study aims to determine if physical exercise can improve the response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy and increase the rate of pCR in breast cancer patients. The study will use a parallel-arm design, with participants randomized 1:1 to either the control group or the experimental group. The control group will receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy alone, while the experimental group will receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy in conjunction with an exercise intervention. The exercise program will consist of combined aerobic and resistance training, and participants will be asked to exercise for 30-60 minutes, 3-5 times per week. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of pCR, and secondary outcome measures will include changes in body composition, quality of life, and biomarkers of inflammation and oxidative stress. The study will enroll 100 participants and follow them for 12 weeks. The results of this study will provide valuable information on the role of physical exercise in improving the response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy in breast cancer patients

- Participant Group/Arm: Standardized After Visit Instructions & Teach Back
- Intervention/Treatment: Behavioral: Standardized After Visit Instructions & Teach Back
- This intervention included the Standardized After Visit Instructions and included teach back, a process by which patients restate in their own words their understanding of their condition, what was discussed in the visit, and what potential changes were made
Reasoning: This arm allows researchers to evaluate the impact of combining standardized after visit instructions with the teach-back method on patient comprehension. By incorporating a feedback mechanism where patients repeat back the information discussed during the visit, researchers can assess whether this interactive approach further enhances patient understanding compared to standardized instructions alone.

Abstract:
Background: Ovarian cancer is the fifth leading cause of cancer death among women in the United States. The majority of patients with ovarian cancer are diagnosed at an advanced stage, and the 5‐year survival rate is 45%. The standard treatment for ovarian cancer is surgery followed by chemotherapy. However, there is no consensus on the optimal duration of maintenance therapy after chemotherapy. The decision to continue maintenance therapy is complex and involves weighing the potential benefits of continued treatment against the potential risks and side effects. The purpose of this study is to develop and evaluate a shared medical decision‐making tool to help patients with ovarian cancer make informed decisions about their maintenance therapy. Methods: The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, a literature review will be conducted to identify the key factors that patients consider when making decisions about maintenance therapy. The findings from the literature review will be used to develop a preliminary decision aid. In the second phase, the decision aid will be pilot tested with a small group of patients with ovarian cancer. The pilot test will involve interviews with patients to assess their understanding of the decision aid and their satisfaction with the decision‐making process. Based on the feedback from the pilot test, the decision aid will be revised and refined. The final decision aid will be evaluated in a randomized controlled trial. The trial will involve 100 patients with ovarian cancer who are considering maintenance therapy. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive the decision aid, while the control group will receive standard care. The primary outcome measure will be patient satisfaction with the decision‐making process. Secondary outcome measures will include patient knowledge about maintenance therapy, patient preferences for maintenance therapy, and patient quality of life. Conclusion: The development and evaluation of a shared medical decision‐making tool for ovarian cancer maintenance therapy has the potential to improve patient outcomes by helping patients make informed decisions about their treatment.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to compare the clinical performance of a maxillary complete denture opposed to a four implant‐assisted mandibular overdenture constructed with the conventional method and CAD/CAM milling. Methods: The study was conducted on 10 patients with a maxillary complete denture and a mandibular complete denture. The patients were randomly divided into two groups. Group I received a maxillary complete denture opposed to a four implant‐assisted mandibular overdenture constructed with the conventional method. Group II received a maxillary complete denture opposed to a four implant‐assisted mandibular overdenture constructed with CAD/CAM milling. The patients were evaluated at baseline and after 6 months of treatment. The evaluation criteria included the number of implants, the number of visits, the number of adjustments, the number of complications, the number of prosthetic failures, the number of patient complaints, the number of patient satisfaction, and the number of patient dissatisfaction. Results: The results showed that the number of visits and the number of adjustments were significantly lower in group II than in group I. The number of complications and the number of prosthetic failures were significantly lower in group II than in group I. The number of patient complaints and the number of patient dissatisfaction were significantly lower in group II than in group I. The number of patient satisfaction was significantly higher in group II than in group I. Conclusion: The results of this study showed that the CAD/CAM milling method was more effective than the conventional method in the construction of four implant‐assisted mandibular overdentures.

This arm allows us to compare the traditional method of constructing mandibular overdentures with the new CAD/CAM technology.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of a new drug, called AZD1775, in patients with advanced solid tumors. AZD1775 is a drug that targets a protein called BRAF. BRAF is a protein that is involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells. AZD1775 is designed to block the activity of BRAF, which may slow the growth of cancer cells. This study will test the safety and effectiveness of AZD1775 in patients with advanced solid tumors that have a mutation in the BRAF gene.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase I/II, open-label, dose-escalation and expansion study of AZD1775 in patients with advanced solid tumors harboring a BRAF V600 mutation. The study will be conducted in two parts: Part 1 will be a dose-escalation study to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended Phase 2 dose (RP2D) of AZD1775. Part 2 will be an expansion study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of AZD1775 at the RP2D in patients with advanced melanoma, non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), and colorectal cancer (CRC). The study will enroll approximately 100 patients in total. Patients will receive AZD1775 orally once daily for 21 days of a 28-day cycle. Treatment will continue until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or withdrawal of consent. The primary objective of Part 1 is to determine the MTD and RP2D of AZD1775. The primary objective of Part 2 is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of AZD1775 at the RP2D in patients with advanced melanoma, NSCLC, and CRC. Detailed Description
-----------------
Dry eye disease is a common condition that affects millions of people worldwide. It is characterized by a lack of tears or poor quality of tears, leading to symptoms such as dryness, irritation, and blurred vision. BUFY01 is a new drug that is being developed to treat dry eye disease. It is a topical eye drop that contains a combination of sodium hyaluronate and trometamol. Sodium hyaluronate is a naturally occurring substance that helps to lubricate the eyes, while trometamol is an anti-inflammatory agent that helps to reduce inflammation and irritation. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, participants will be randomly assigned to receive either BUFY01 or a placebo (a substance that looks and feels like the study drug but does not contain any active ingredients). Participants will use the study drug four times a day for 12 weeks. In the second phase, participants will be switched to the other study drug for an additional 12 weeks. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of BUFY01 by measuring changes in symptoms, signs, and quality of life.

The intervention for the experimental arm involves passive heating achieved by immersion in a hot tub at 40 degrees Celsius for approximately 45 minutes. This intervention aims to raise the core temperature of the participants to 38.5 degrees Celsius, simulating a mild exercise-like response. The duration and temperature of the hot tub immersion are carefully selected to ensure safety and effectiveness in promoting cardioprotective benefits.

Other

Primary outcome measure
=================
The primary outcome measure is the change in cardiac output measured by cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) before and after the intervention. Cardiac output is a measure of the amount of blood pumped by the heart per minute and is an important indicator of cardiovascular health.

Secondary outcome measures
=================
The secondary outcome measures include changes in other cardiovascular parameters such as heart rate, blood pressure, and vascular function, as well as changes in physical function and quality of life. These outcomes will be assessed using a variety of methods, including physical assessments, questionnaires, and interviews.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a 12-week, 12-session, group-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) intervention for patients with chronic pain and comorbid depression. The study will compare the effectiveness of the intervention to a waitlist control group.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a waitlist control group. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the waitlist control group. The intervention group will receive the 12-week, 12-session, group-based CBT intervention, while the waitlist control group will receive the intervention after the 12-week waiting period. The primary outcome measure will be the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), which is a self-report measure of depression symptoms. Secondary outcome measures will include the Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS), the Pain Disability Index (PDI), and the Pain Anxiety Symptoms Scale (PASS). The study will also assess the feasibility of the intervention, including participant retention and satisfaction.

A Randomized Controlled Trial of a Group-Based Cognitive Behavioral Therapy Intervention for Patients With Chronic Pain and Comorbid Depression

The VIOP will consist of 12 weekly sessions of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) delivered via videoconference, with each session lasting approximately 60 minutes. The program will be delivered by a trained therapist and will be tailored to the individual needs of each participant. The primary outcome measure will be the number of days of abstinence from alcohol, as measured by self-report and confirmed by urine toxicology testing. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in alcohol consumption, alcohol-related consequences, and quality of life. The study will also assess the feasibility and acceptability of the VIOP, as well as the cost-effectiveness of the program. The study will be conducted in Ontario, Canada, and will enroll a total of 100 participants with moderate to severe AUD.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a virtual intensive outpatient program (VIOP) for the treatment of alcohol use disorder (AUD). The study will be conducted in a single-group, open-label design. Participants will be recruited from the community and will be required to meet the following inclusion criteria: age 18 or older, able to communicate and provide informed consent in English, diagnosed with moderate to severe AUD, and motivated to abstain from alcohol for the duration of the treatment. Participants will be enrolled in the Ontario Health Insurance Plan (OHIP) and will have access to a private location for the duration of the program. Exclusion criteria include severe medical or psychiatric comorbidity, active suicidal ideation, opioid use disorder or sedative use disorder in the past year, alcohol withdrawal delirium, current pregnancy or breastfeeding, enrollment in another conflicting study, or planning to be out of the province during the program. The study will consist of a 12-week virtual intensive outpatient program (VIOP) that will be delivered through a secure online platform. The program will include weekly individual and group therapy sessions, as well as daily check-ins and monitoring of alcohol use. The primary outcome measure will be the number of days of abstinence from alcohol during the 12-week treatment period. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in alcohol consumption, quality of life, and mental health symptoms. The study will also assess the feasibility and acceptability of the VIOP program.

-----------------
Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a chronic relapsing brain disease that affects millions of people worldwide. It is characterized by a persistent and compulsive pattern of alcohol use that leads to significant impairment in social, occupational, and other important areas of functioning. Despite the availability of evidence-based treatments, many individuals with AUD do not receive adequate treatment due to a lack of access to care, stigma, and other barriers. Brief summary
=================
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the NaviFUS System in patients with drug-resistant temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE). The study will enroll patients with TLE who have failed to achieve seizure control with at least two anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs). Patients will undergo a pre-surgical evaluation to confirm the diagnosis of TLE and identify the likely site of seizure onset. If the patient is eligible for surgery, they will undergo a surgical procedure to implant the NaviFUS System. The system consists of a small device that is implanted under the skin and connected to the brain through a thin wire. The device is designed to deliver electrical stimulation to the brain to prevent seizures. Patients will be monitored for 12 months after the implantation to assess the safety and efficacy of the device. The primary outcome measure is the change in seizure frequency from baseline to 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in quality of life, cognitive function, and mood.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the motor-cable-driven rehabilitation robotic system for stroke wrist and forearm rehabilitation.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The motor-cable-driven rehabilitation robotic system is a new rehabilitation device that can provide a more natural and effective rehabilitation training for stroke patients. The system consists of a motor-cable-driven mechanism, a control system, and a software system. The motor-cable-driven mechanism is used to provide resistance to the patient's wrist and forearm during rehabilitation training. The control system is used to control the speed and direction of the motor-cable-driven mechanism. The software system is used to provide feedback to the patient and the therapist. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, the safety of the motor-cable-driven rehabilitation robotic system will be evaluated. In the second phase, the efficacy of the motor-cable-driven rehabilitation robotic system will be evaluated.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of a 12-week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be conducted in two phases. The first phase will be a 12-week exercise program, and the second phase will be a 12-week follow-up period. The exercise program will consist of three sessions per week, each lasting 60 minutes. The program will include aerobic exercise, resistance training, and flexibility exercises. The intensity of the exercise will be adjusted based on the patient's heart rate and perceived exertion. The primary outcome measure will be the quality of life of the patients, as measured by the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ). Secondary outcome measures will include the 6-minute walk test, the Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnea scale, and the COPD Assessment Test (CAT).

Effect of a 12-week Exercise Program on the Quality of Life of Patients With Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

* Behavioral: Exercise program

Abstract:
Background: Sepsis is a life‐threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection. The incidence of sepsis is increasing worldwide, and it is the leading cause of death in intensive care units (ICUs). Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common complication of sepsis, and it is associated with increased mortality and morbidity. Vasorin is a novel biomarker that has been shown to be a predictor of AKI in patients with sepsis. However, the prognostic value of vasorin in patients with septic shock and AKI is not well understood. Methods: This is a prospective observational study conducted in the ICUs of two tertiary care hospitals in India. The study population included patients with septic shock and AKI. The primary outcome was 28‐day mortality, and the secondary outcomes included length of stay in the ICU and hospital, and the need for renal replacement therapy. Results: A total of 100 patients were included in the study. The median age of the patients was 55 years, and the majority were male (60%). Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life (QoL) of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to either an exercise group or a control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The QoL of the patients was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 65.2 ± 7.1 years, and the mean body mass index was 28.3 ± 4.1 kg/m2. The mean SGRQ score at baseline was 49.1 ± 10.1 in the exercise group and 48.9 ± 10.2 in the control group. After the intervention, the mean SGRQ score decreased to 38.2 ± 9.3 in the exercise group and increased to 50.1 ± 10.3 in the control group. The difference in the mean change in SGRQ score between the two groups was statistically significant (p < 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the QoL of patients with COPD.

=================
Primary dysmenorrhea is a common condition that affects many women of reproductive age. It is characterized by severe pain in the lower abdomen, lower back, and thighs during menstruation. The pain can be debilitating and interfere with daily activities. Ibuprofen is a commonly used medication for the treatment of primary dysmenorrhea, but it can have side effects such as gastrointestinal bleeding and kidney damage. Dark chocolate and young coconut water have been shown to have anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties, and they may be effective in reducing the intensity of primary dysmenorrhea. The aim of this study is to compare the effectiveness of dark chocolate, young coconut water, and Ibuprofen in reducing the intensity of primary dysmenorrhea. The study will involve 120 participants who will be randomly assigned to one of the three treatment groups. The participants will be asked to consume either dark chocolate, young coconut water, or Ibuprofen during their menstrual period. The intensity of their pain will be measured using a visual analog scale before and after the treatment. The results of the study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of dark chocolate, young coconut water, and Ibuprofen in reducing the intensity of primary dysmenorrhea.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a combination of botensilimab and balstilimab in patients with advanced solid tumors. Methods: This was a phase 1b, open‐label, multicenter study. Patients with advanced solid tumors were enrolled and received botensilimab (10 mg/kg) and balstilimab (3 mg/kg) intravenously every 3 weeks. The primary endpoint was the objective response rate (ORR) per RECIST v1.1. Results: A total of 20 patients were enrolled. The median age was 59 years (range, 30‐75 years), and 12 patients (60%) were male. The most common tumor types were colorectal cancer (n = 10, 50%), non‐small cell lung cancer (n = 4, 20%), and gastric cancer (n = 3, 15%). The ORR was 25% (95% CI, 8.2‐50.0%), and the disease control rate was 65% (95% CI, 37.2‐85.8%). The median progression‐free survival was 2.9 months (95% CI, 1.9‐4.0 months), and the median overall survival was 10.1 months (95% CI, 5.0‐15.2 months). The most common treatment‐related adverse events were diarrhea (n = 10, 50%), fatigue (n = 8, 40%), and nausea (n = 6, 30%). Conclusions: The combination of botensilimab and balstilimab showed promising antitumor activity and manageable safety in patients with advanced solid tumors.

Abstract:
Background: The UNICORN trial is a phase 2, multicenter, open‐label, non‐randomized, interventional trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of targeted treatments in molecularly selected resectable colorectal cancer (CRC). Methods: The trial will enroll patients with resectable CRC who are candidates for curative surgery. Patients will be stratified based on their molecular profile and assigned to one of five cohorts: Cohort 1: HER2 positive; Cohort 2: POLE/D1 proof‐read domain pathogenic mutation associated with ultra‐mutated status; Cohort 3: pMMR/MSS status, RAS and BRAF wild type status, and PRESSING negative status; Cohort 4: pMMR/MSS status and absence of HER2 overexpression/amplification, absence of POLE/D1 proof‐read domain pathogenic mutation associated with ultra‐mutated status; and Cohort 5: pMMR/MSS status and absence of HER2 overexpression/amplification, absence of POLE/D1 proof‐read domain pathogenic mutation associated with ultra‐mutated status. The primary endpoint is the pathological complete response (pCR) rate. Secondary endpoints include the safety and tolerability of the treatments, overall survival, disease‐free survival, and quality of life. Conclusion: The UNICORN trial will provide valuable insights into the efficacy and safety of targeted treatments in molecularly selected resectable CRC. The results of this trial will inform future clinical trials and improve the management of patients with resectable CRC.

Absolutely. For the intervention, access to the gallbladder will be performed from the stomach or duodenum using a LAMS with an electrocautery-enhanced delivery system such as Hot Axios or Hot Spaxus. The size of the stent used will depend on the size of the largest gallstone, with a 10 mm diameter stent used for gallstones smaller than 10 mm and a larger diameter (≥15 mm stent) used for gallstones larger than 10 mm. Additionally, if needed, colecystoscopy lithotripsy will be performed using mechanical lithotripsy and/or laser lithotripsy. The first cholecystoscopy will be done 2 weeks after the initial procedure.

Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease who will undergo real repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) sessions.
Intervention/Treatment: The intervention involves 4 daily 25-minute high-frequency rTMS sessions over one week using a 70-mm figure-eight coil at 20Hz. Target localization will be performed with a stereotaxic neuronavigation system.
Reasoning: This arm is essential to test the efficacy of non-invasive stimulation techniques, specifically real rTMS, in modulating the default mode network (DMN) in individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease. By targeting this specific population with a known genetic risk factor for AD, the study aims to assess the potential benefits of this intervention in early stages of the disease.

2. Sham Comparator: sham-rTMS
Participant Group/Arm: This arm serves as the control group in the study.
Intervention/Treatment: Participants in this arm will undergo 4 daily 25-minute sham-rTMS sessions over one week, where the sham condition will mimic the real rTMS protocol but with a sham coil.
Reasoning: The inclusion of a sham comparator arm is crucial to establish the efficacy of the real rTMS intervention. By comparing the outcomes of the experimental arm with the control arm, researchers can determine whether the observed effects are due to the specific intervention or simply a placebo effect. This design helps ensure the validity and reliability of the study results.

Thank you for providing such detailed criteria. Now, let's move on to the design details of your trial. Can you provide me with the primary purpose, allocation, intervention model, and masking?

Great! Now that we have all the necessary information, let's design the study arms. Based on the criteria and goals of your trial, I suggest the following arms:

Study Arm 1:
Participant Group/Arm: LRAMPS group
Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: LRAMPS
Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will undergo laparoscopic radical antegrade modular pancreatosplenectomy (LRAMPS) surgery. This arm is necessary to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LRAMPS with those undergoing LDP. The LRAMPS procedure involves the removal of Gerota's fascia and perirenal fat capsule, with the option to perform anterior or posterior LRAMPS depending on the resection of the left adrenal gland. The removal of specific lymph nodes is also outlined based on the tumor location.

Study Arm 2:
Participant Group/Arm: LDP group
Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: LDP
Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will undergo laparoscopic distal pancreatosplecnectomy (LDP) surgery. This arm is essential to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LDP with those undergoing LRAMPS. The LDP procedure involves dissection behind the fusion fascia and the removal of specific lymph nodes based on the tumor location. This arm allows for a comparison of outcomes between LDP and LRAMPS in the context of early-stage left-sided pancreatic cancer.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the exercise group (n = 30) and the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not. The quality of life of the patients was evaluated using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) before and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 65.2 ± 7.1 years, and 40 (66.7%) were male. The mean SGRQ score was 49.1 ± 11.2 before the intervention and 43.2 ± 10.4 after the intervention in the exercise group, and 49.1 ± 11.2 before the intervention and 48.1 ± 10.9 after the intervention in the control group. The mean SGRQ score was significantly lower in the exercise group than in the control group after the intervention (p = 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.
